researchIntrest.title: Nucleo Mitochondrial Communicome
researchIntrest.description: The central hypothesis that guides our research is that stochastic, endogenous nuclear DNA damage alters cellular and metabolic programs, leading to progression of multiple, age- related degenerative diseases.

researchIntrest.title: DNA damage and Heart disease
researchIntrest.description: Problems with DNA repair pathways have been observed in cardiac failure patients. Additionally, recent data suggests that pediatric patients treated with genotoxic agents, develop disabling or life-threatening age- related diseases compared to their siblings.

researchIntrest.title: Genotoxic stress response in post-mitotic cells
researchIntrest.description: Replicative cells respond to DNA damage with cell fate decisions such as cell cycle arrest, cellular senescence or apoptosis.

team.name: Aditi Gurkar
team.title: Principal Investigator
team.Description: Aditi U. Gurkar is an Assistant Professor in the Aging Institute, Division of Geriatric Medicine at the University of Pittsburgh. I believe that aging is one true mystery that surrounds us. Aging is inescapable and unfortunately the principal risk factor for a number of diseases including cancer, heart disease and Alzheimer disease (AD).

team.name: Shruthi Hamsanathan
team.title: Research Scientist
team.Description: My research interest has always been towards understanding complex biological mechanisms. I am particularly fascinated by transport mechanisms occurring at biological membranes. I find this as an interesting challenge for a cell, as it should maintain the membrane integrity while it transports proteins or other biomolecules across the membrane for survival.

team.name: Lucile Marchal
team.Description: I have always been interested in biology and had the chance to study biochemistry, cellular biology and physiology at the University of Besançon (France) during my B.S. equivalent. I then joined the bioengineering program of the Polytech'Nice Engineering School of the University of Nice (France), where I learned more about biotechnologies and pharmacology.

team.name: Mohamad Nayal
team.Description: My name Mo Nayal and I am excited to be joining Dr. Aditi Gurkar's lab at the Aging Institute! I'm originally from New Jersey but have lived in Philadelphia for the past 7 years where I attended Drexel University and worked at the University Pennsylvania's Gene Therapy Program.

news.name: TEDxPittsburgh
news.description: Our own Aditi Gurkar will be one of the featured speakers at TEDxPittsburgh! “How old are you? No, Really.” She'll be introducing the difference between biological and chronological age, and then discussing the pursuit of a biological clock that might facilitate a personalized intervention to slow the process.

news.name: Testimonial from our summer Undergrad from Oxford University, Roshan K.
news.description: Over 8 weeks this summer, I worked on an independent research project in the Gurkar Lab at the Aging Institute. This was my first experience of research, and so having Dr Gurkar as my supervisor made all the difference in the world. She led me through the stages of planning out my project, data collection, and even data analysis, and the skills and knowledge which I gained from my time at the lab have been absolutely invaluable back at university in Oxford. Dr Gurkar and the whole team at the Gurkar lab are all lovely people and were very enthusiastic in welcoming me to Pittsburgh and to their lab. They were all very happy to help me with the details of my lab work and the different assays which I carried out, and I am really happy that I had the chance to know everyone there over my summer! Working at the Aging Institute, I had the opportunity to listen to fascinating talks from experts in the field of aging, on subjects such as novel senolytic drugs and telomere biology. However, my most memorable experiences of the summer included the time our lab spent together, including our lab picnic in Oakland at the end of summer, weekly lab meetings and journal club (always sure to feature a sweet treat!), and the lab potluck we had right before I left. I would thoroughly recommend the Gurkar lab to any students who would like to gain research experience in a fun and welcoming environment.
